displayed_text: Patient: My hip primarily, the hip and lumbar region. Doctor: And that’s your right hip? Patient: Right hip, yeah and then that was ten doses and the lower femur, five doses of treatments. Doctor: And how are you feeling? Patient: Pretty good. Doctor: How’s your pain? Patient: No pain. There’s just a little; I know my right hip is there. You know I know what the sensation is. Doctor: So the radiation helped? Patient: Yes, I think so, yes. Doctor: But you still need to take the opioids. Patient: Yeah, yeah, but not as much. I’ve cut down. Doctor: So the OxyContin was two times a day and now you’re once a day.

Patient: Oh, shoot. Oh, God. Doctor: But that’s a lot of travelling, man. Family Member: It’s very interesting. Patient: Oh, my goodness. Whew. That plane ride was a trip. Family Member: We was, uh, kind of like laughing come down here to Baltimore. We were like, Baltimore’s not too far from South Africa with the living conditions. You know? Patient: With how some of these people live. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: I’m like, wow. Patient: My, gosh. We was in Langa, and then Langa- Doctor: So did, was that part of the tour to see that or that was just you could not see that in just where you were going? Patient: Everything was part of the tour. Yeah. Family Member: Um hum. It’s all included. Patient: Everything is, and then you have some passages-

Patient: Okay. Healthcare Professional: Do you want me to step out for a few? Doctor: I just uh, you can stay, I mean it doesn’t matter to me. I did realize I wasn’t quite done because I had gone back to get paperwork. Healthcare Professional: Alright well I’ll step out. Doctor: Yeah like give me like two minutes, we’ll be set. Okay (door closes) Patient: Okay. (Pause 30 seconds) Doctor: Here you go. If you can sign here. Here you go. (sound of signing papers) Healthcare Professional 1: Sorry, just me. So I sent all your scripts (door closes) Patient: Okay. Healthcare Professional 1: …electronically to the K____ pharmacy. Patient: Okay, thanks. Healthcare Professional 1: That’s your oxycodone, the Xanax and that the – this is the one to help you urinate. That’s Tamsulosin which is generic for Flomax. All your other medications, your vitamins, prednisone, your cholesterol medication, everything else.

Patient: Couldn’t handle that flight. Oh, gosh. Family Member: The flight is so long. Doctor: Did you fly like connect somewhere? Patient: Yeah. We had to go to Dubai. And then from Dubai, was nine hours to Dubai. Doctor: Nine hours to Dubai? Then how long? Patient: From Dubai to South Africa was nine hours. Doctor: How far to Dubai? It’s like twelve hours? Patient: Oh, man, it was about fourteen, sixteen hours. Doctor: Man, you guys are- Doctor: You had to travel. Doctor: Yeah. They do like the circle route, I guess. Patient: Yeah. I don’t understand it.

Patient: Fine. Doctor: Okay. Good to see you. Family Member: Thank you. Doctor: A ___ may want you to fill out something, so. Family Member: Okay. Patient: Yeah and where will I get the form for the appointment? Doctor: When you head out front, along that purple wall there there’s people there. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: It should be pretty clean and nobody out there now. There might be somebody there and there may not be. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay, let me see if A ___ needs to see you before you go. Patient: Okay. Do you have some paperclips? That’s fine. Okay.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, your January/February scan had maybe something on your adrenal glands, maybe something in your liver, maybe some clumpy lymph nodes, and you’re like oh, okay. So, when I sent you over for like additional, you know, trials you had areas to measure outside your bone but then you kind of don’t. So, on your last CAT scan we couldn’t see anything where the liver was so that’s just not there, the lymph nodes kind of where the adrenal area was is enlarged so you don’t fit that. Oh, that’s wonderful. You made my life a living bleep when I was like oh, yay, but oh, yay, oh, yay, oh. Patient: Right. Doctor: So, I’m thrilled that you don’t have the cancer that we say earlier that might have been from the pills you were on Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: but then I’m kind of stuck in terms of well, I’m not really sure if I know where you are right now in October. So, sometimes when I get a little bit stuck and I’m trying to well, there’s this and that, just stop. It doesn’t have to be a mystery because we can just do a full set. So, like you should get a bone scan because the last time was July and we’re in October. You’re in pain so maybe I got to look for new spots that we have to try to treat. That’s one. Then, you know, a bone scan and then a CAT scan, but one that also includes the chest to make sure I’m not missing anything up higher that maybe is causing some of the lower pain. So, I think from here to here and your bone scan we can get that in a few days. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I’m not gonna fuss. I’m gonna fast forward to say well, whatever that shows I think the question is, you know, what are my options. So, here’s where I’m at. If it’s more than bone, meaning, oh, shoot, maybe that thingy in the liver and the lymph nodes and all that is actually there again and that other one was sort of a fake out then I think you need chemo and I think we’ve been stalling enough for a while that the inevitable is about to happen Mr. H____ you just, you’re gonna, we’re just gonna have to do it Patient: Okay. Doctor: and that’s with docetaxel and Taxotere is the name of the chemo and we do have studies with that so I just, you know, I always want to make sure we talk about that. So, you’d get on Taxotere just alone once every three weeks. It’s an hour infusion. Standard of care anywhere you go in the US. Patient: Okay. Doctor: and then our studies are Taxotere plus high-dose vitamin C versus just the Taxotere. So, two-thirds of the people will get vitamin C. The other one third will just get the chemo. So, everybody gets chemo no matter how I swing this

Family Member: Yeah, we go on vacation and I have to pull him or push him upstairs. I’m trying to figure out something for this cruise we’re going on so I can pull him upstairs. Patient: You know it’s not excruciating but it’s uh, uh… Doctor: No but that is a - Patient: Yeah. Doctor: -major bothersome… Family Member: And I’m wondering if it was part of - Doctor: No if it’s some of the pressure. Yeah although if it hurts after exertion it may not be nerve related. I wish they would have done and EMG at the same time of your feet. Patient: I know it. I know it. Doctor: Yeah if you had mentioned this - Family Member: Well yeah. Doctor: They would have done both. Family Member: I didn’t think about that.

Patient: Uh-huh, yes, uh-huh. Yeah. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I’ve been working, and, uh, I got off work a little early today to come to the appointment, so. Doctor: Okay. Okay. Fine. Patient: And stuff like that. Yep. I’m just staying on course, believing in myself, believing in God, as usual. Doctor: Right. Patient: I know it’s going to get better. Doctor: Alright. Patient: Uh, uh, yes. Doctor: So we have to watch you closely. I don’t know whether, how much, how much you remember when we talked about the pathology and that it invaded the seminal vesicle. Do you remember that discussion? Patient: Yeah. You were saying something, about something, something. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. It went into the seminal vesicle and so, uh, we’re going to have to just, just watch you closely. Right now, everything is fine and it may continue to be that way. Okay?

Patient: Right. Doctor: He’s just so you know because I guess your family and - Patient: Yeah. Doctor: - his family are all sort of active, you know he’s very happy to you know be a part of that process, but also if you’re getting it locally and getting it done - Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay, so I’m not going to put any additional appointments in here. I’ll let D take it over from here. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Let me see if she’s out here to sort of get a sense that I can give you some feedback that it will be in the next day or the next week to sort of say to you - Patient: And then you will let us know about chemo Doctor: Yeah, we’ve got a little bit of a window, so we probably have until early February to get started. Patient: Oh so it won’t get started before that? Doctor: No, it could start as soon as you participate in the study, we can do that, but it’s not urgent that it has to be done before Christmas or before the new year’s or before Martin Luther King - Patient: Okay.

Patient: Right. Doctor: and things may change when you’re on the study and we have to sort of make these changes ourselves so it’s better if we just do it. Family Member: Yeah, I agree Healthcare Professional: He can’t see the pain clinic here? Doctor: He can see the pain clinic here but are you almost out of your Percocet? Patient: Yeah, I want to say I have maybe, yeah. Doctor: Okay. Because the other thought is Dr. S____ is here today, right? Healthcare Professional: Yes? Doctor: We have our own pain person. So, that way Family Member: Yay Doctor: if we have to transition, you’re right here too. Ah hah. So, you don’t have to Family Member: Right.

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So that is why we give both drugs in combination. And what happens is on a monthly basis through about twenty-eight day treatment cycles the testosterone goes from being super-high, much higher than your body would be able to make on its own back down to super-low. PAT Uh huh. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So every twenty-eight days which is roughly every four weeks, your testosterone will spike for a few days and then within about a week it will drop down to the very low levels. Patient: When you say spike, what numbers have you seen? Doctor: Right, so I told you before that a real low testosterone level for someone your age might be let’s say a hundred fifty to two hundred milligrams per deciliter. Here, they’re talking about between one thousand and one thousand five hundred milligrams per deciliter. So it’s a five- to ten-fold increase above the physiological level. So we call this super-physiological. That means higher than physiological. Patient: Right, okay. Doctor: So again, since you’re not eligible for that at this point in time - Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: A minimum PSA for that trial has to be above one. Patient: Okay. Doctor: One point zero. But just to prepare for the future –

Patient: Okay do you think… Doctor: Because we’ll really have exhausted that Xtandi is not working definitely before we decide to switch to Lynparza at that point. Patient: How soon will you know? I mean the… Family Member: With the BET. Doctor: With the BET? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I’m thinking four to six weeks will give us at least an inkling if it’s doing something. Even if it’s stabilizes the PSA. We kind of have a clue that it’s doing what it’s supposed to. But to give it a fair trial, typically six to twelve weeks is required on any new medication I would say. Patient: Do you think that in the meantime the cancer will increase? Doctor: It seems very unlikely to me. Okay. Mainly because your scans haven’t changed. If they had… Patient: Except for the brightness. Doctor: Except for the brightness, yeah. If they had changed, you know if you had three new spots now, we would probably be having a different discussion. We’d say well I think we need to – got to go to chemotherapy or something that will work quickly or maybe Lynparza give that a try. But I think we have room to wait and see if we can squeeze any effect from the Xtandi if that is the resistance pathway that your cancer is stuck at which… Family Member: Mm Hmm.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But I need to be assured as you guys do also. Family Member: Right. Doctor: That there’s nothing new or that these guys all of a sudden didn’t wake up and go, yeah, well, we were sleeping. Family Member: Right. Doctor: All those lymph nodes and now we’re awake. And we would know if we’re awake because it would be bigger or if it was new. Like, wait a minute. Patient: Hum. Doctor: That wasn’t big before, what we’ve got there. Family Member: Right. Right. Doctor: So we’re going to meet again after so we all describe the tests together so that you know what it is like. Family Member: Oh, okay. Patient: Essentially again with the shot and stuff, it didn’t change.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.3 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::3 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.strongly agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::strongly agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.disagree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::disagree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.strongly disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.::: strongly disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Patient: Yeah. That’s a good point. Right. Doctor: Yeah. I mean, I think if you want to explore that, my feeling would be if you can get it on the study, well and good. If not, you should explore if you can go and, you know, I don’t know what it costs there, and, you know, what you have to pay. Family Member: If you can get on, on the study, which would involve the scan, doing the scan? Doctor: Doing the scan first. Family Member: Yeah. Of course. Doctor: But even there, they would do the scan first, because if it’s not going to help you, they’re not going to push you to get the treatment that’s not going to work. Family Member: Yeah. Yeah. Patient: And that’s one treatment every-? Doctor: Six weeks. Patient: Six weeks? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: For-?

Family Member: No, I don’t make him work hard. It’s me. He’ll say oh you missed a spot and it’s like oh okay. Family Member: It’s okay. I get him to dust. He gets the easy stuff. Doctor: Alright. Family Member: I’ll do the rest. Doctor: Oh my gosh. You have a busy week. Okay so let me have S___ come in then. We’ll get that – all of those testing going. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay you’re not going over to the infusion today. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And uh we’ll go from there. Patient: Alright. Doctor: Now prescription wise do you need anything? Patient: No.
